), are estimated as three independent transition vectors: the transition
transitions are deterministic based on the current capacity and
action to add capacity as described hereafter.
is the action space, or set of possible actions.
describes whether a static or ﬂexible dam is chosen, and whether
infrastructure capacity is expanded in later time periods.
correspond, respectively, to no change, adding a small static alternative, adding a
large static alternative, adding a ﬂexible alternative, and expanding the ﬂexible
alternative. The choices are constrained by time period and available infrastructure
is the optimal policy or choice of action.
the capital costs of infrastructure and damages if the infrastructure fails to meet
infrastructure including capital costs (capex) and operating costs (opex).

in our base case based on estimates of water productivity in Kenya from
is the volume of unmet demand as a function of the climate

performance is not measured until the beginning of the second 20-year time period.
. Climate impacts on river runoff depend on
changes in month-to-month variability in precipitation and temperature in addi-
tion to changes in the mean. We model these two changes separately. To develop
applied to GCM projections. This non-parametric statistical
approach allows us to impose the mean
from the SDP while also capturing
the standard deviation in monthly values and month-to-month autocorrelation
projected by the GCMs. This approach was chosen for its simplicity, ease of
implementation, and application in long-term water supply; future studies could
use other non-parametric approaches such as the local polynomial regression
. For each 20-year time period, we employ the kNN
approach to generate 100 samples of 20-year long monthly time-series of
The resulting time series are then applied to the rainfall-runoff model presented
time series are input to a
hydrological model to assess the impacts on runoff. We use CLIRUN II, the latest
in a family of hydrological models developed to assess the impact of climate
. CLIRUN II is a two-layer, conceptual, lumped-watershed
rainfall-runoff model. It averages soil parameters over the watershed and models
runoff at one gauge station at the mouth of the basin. It can be run on a monthly or
daily time step. Using the kNN generated samples of
a corresponding 100 samples of 20-year long monthly timeseries of runoff.
CLIRUN II is calibrated using 14 years of monthly streamﬂow data. Only one
streamﬂow gauge, RGS 3MA03, is available in the Mwache basin
directly upstream of the dam location, making it representative for this study. The
same monthly temperature and precipitation data from CRU used in the Bayesian
climate analysis is used to calibrate CLIRUN II for consistency. This temperature
and precipitation data is different than the local data used in the previous World
, leading to different calibration results but similar performance
Our analysis using CLIRUN II and the reservoir sizing model conﬁrms that the
80 MCM dam meets the reliability targets in the current and expected future
climate but does not meet reliability targets if the climate gets substantially warmer
and drier. The 120 MCM dam meets reliability targets across all projected future
. Capex and opex estimates for the small and
large dams were developed using the cost tool from the previous World Bank
. For the ﬂexible dam, the cost per m
assumed to be 50% greater than that of the original capacity. Capex and opex
estimates for the RO desalination plants were developed using the Cost Estimator
The infrastructure operation model includes ﬁxed dam operations (and
desalination operations when necessary) that seek to meet the speciﬁed yield target
while accounting for dead storage, net evaporation, and environmental ﬂows.
Unmet demand is measured for each of the 100 streamﬂow time series, and the
average 20-year unmet demand is used to characterize
). We acknowledge that assuming reservoir operations that are ﬁxed in time
is a limitation given that adaptive reservoir operations would likely reduce the need
for additional capacity; future work could optimize the reservoir operations to each

. GCM projections are publicly available from the respective sources listed in
Supplementary Table 1. Streamﬂow data is available in Supplementary Data 1.
